706006f-a.title: Brooklyn: New Lots Avenue - Van Siclen Avenue
706006f-a.text:
(1)
569 New Lots Ave., north side, east of Van Siclen Ave., showing
the home of the Van Siclen's from about 1730 to 1887. This house
was said to have been erected in 1730. It is now, 1929, used as a
gasoline station. John Van Siclen during the War of 1812, was em-
ployed by the government as a mail carrier. The parsonage of the
Dutch reformed church is visible on the left.
About 1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
NAY BE REPRODUCED.
(2)
The same, another view.
About 1929.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY PE REPRODUCED.
706006f-a.folder: New Lots Avenue & Van Siclen Avenue, Brooklyn, NY

706486f-a.title: Brooklyn: Riverdale Avenue - Van Siclen Avenue
706486f-a.text:
Rtiverdale Av., at the N.W. corner of Van Siclen Ave., showing the Par-
sonage of a Dutch Reformed Church. It was demolished in March 1929.
Now a series of 1-story brick buildings occupy the site.
May 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
706486f-a.folder: Riverdale Avenue & Van Siclen Avenue, Brooklyn, NY
